ticket.tag: 3.0 activerecord bugmash enhancement migrations mysql patch tests
ticket.title: :limit for primary key columns
ticket.original-body:
The primary key size for MySQL is currently hardcoded to int(11) in ActiveRecord. I have attempted to add support for the :limit option so you can do something like this.
@@@ ruby create_table :people, :id => false do |t| t.primary_key :id, :limit => 8 ... end @@@
The attached patches (for edge and 2.1) make this work for migrations but I had trouble on the schema dumper side of things and gave up because it was getting too messy. Still, we might be able to come up with the right solution through some discussion here.
The problem was that information about the primary key is retrieved through pk_and_sequence_for. This would effectively have to become pk_and_sequence_and_limit_for and the primary key would have to be explicitly given in the create_table block unless the limit size matches the default. This alone wasn't pretty but then I realised I needed access to extract_limit from the MysqlColumn class before the instances of this class are created. Like I said, messy!
So, any ideas?
ticket.latest-body:
The primary key size for MySQL is currently hardcoded to int(11) in ActiveRecord. I have attempted to add support for the :limit option so you can do something like this.
@@@ ruby create_table :people, :id => false do |t| t.primary_key :id, :limit => 8 ... end @@@
The attached patches (for edge and 2.1) make this work for migrations but I had trouble on the schema dumper side of things and gave up because it was getting too messy. Still, we might be able to come up with the right solution through some discussion here.
The problem was that information about the primary key is retrieved through pk_and_sequence_for. This would effectively have to become pk_and_sequence_and_limit_for and the primary key would have to be explicitly given in the create_table block unless the limit size matches the default. This alone wasn't pretty but then I realised I needed access to extract_limit from the MysqlColumn class before the instances of this class are created. Like I said, messy!
So, any ideas?
ticket.original-body-html:
The primary key size for MySQL is currently hardcoded to int(11) in ActiveRecord. I have attempted to add support for the :limit option so you can do something like this.


create_table :people, :id => false do |t|
  t.primary_key :id, :limit => 8
  ...
end

The attached patches (for edge and 2.1) make this work for migrations but I had trouble on the schema dumper side of things and gave up because it was getting too messy. Still, we might be able to come up with the right solution through some discussion here.

The problem was that information about the primary key is retrieved through pk_and_sequence_for. This would effectively have to become pk_and_sequence_and_limit_for and the primary key would have to be explicitly given in the create_table block unless the limit size matches the default. This alone wasn't pretty but then I realised I needed access to extract_limit from the MysqlColumn class before the instances of this class are created. Like I said, messy!

So, any ideas?

version.body:
The primary key size for MySQL is currently hardcoded to int(11) in ActiveRecord. I have attempted to add support for the :limit option so you can do something like this.
@@@ ruby create_table :people, :id => false do |t| t.primary_key :id, :limit => 8 ... end @@@
The attached patches (for edge and 2.1) make this work for migrations but I had trouble on the schema dumper side of things and gave up because it was getting too messy. Still, we might be able to come up with the right solution through some discussion here.
The problem was that information about the primary key is retrieved through pk_and_sequence_for. This would effectively have to become pk_and_sequence_and_limit_for and the primary key would have to be explicitly given in the create_table block unless the limit size matches the default. This alone wasn't pretty but then I realised I needed access to extract_limit from the MysqlColumn class before the instances of this class are created. Like I said, messy!
So, any ideas?
version.body-html:
The primary key size for MySQL is currently hardcoded to int(11) in ActiveRecord. I have attempted to add support for the :limit option so you can do something like this.


create_table :people, :id => false do |t|
  t.primary_key :id, :limit => 8
  ...
end

The attached patches (for edge and 2.1) make this work for migrations but I had trouble on the schema dumper side of things and gave up because it was getting too messy. Still, we might be able to come up with the right solution through some discussion here.

The problem was that information about the primary key is retrieved through pk_and_sequence_for. This would effectively have to become pk_and_sequence_and_limit_for and the primary key would have to be explicitly given in the create_table block unless the limit size matches the default. This alone wasn't pretty but then I realised I needed access to extract_limit from the MysqlColumn class before the instances of this class are created. Like I said, messy!

So, any ideas?
version.tag: 2.1 activerecord edge enhancement experimental migrations mysql patch
version.title: :limit for primary key columns

version.body: Thinking about it, I suppose the primary key could always be given explicitly in the create_table block. That would make the underlying code a bit simpler. That doesn't solve the problem though.
version.body-html: Thinking about it, I suppose the primary key could always be given explicitly in the create_table block. That would make the underlying code a bit simpler. That doesn't solve the problem though.
version.tag: 2.1 activerecord edge enhancement experimental migrations mysql patch
version.title: :limit for primary key columns

version.body: All by best ideas come to me in the shower. :D I later realised that always creating the primary key explicitly in the block *does* solve the problem since the column instances have been created by that point. Here are new patches, complete with a new test. I had to modify the test for custom primary key names slightly.
version.body-html: All by best ideas come to me in the shower. :D I later realised that always creating the primary key explicitly in the block does solve the problem since the column instances have been created by that point. Here are new patches, complete with a new test. I had to modify the test for custom primary key names slightly.

version.tag: 2.1 activerecord edge enhancement migrations mysql patch tests
version.title: :limit for primary key columns

version.body: Sorry, one more fix. Changed the default :limit from 11 to 4, otherwise it'll add :limit in the schema when it doesn't need to since 4 is returned by int, not 11.
version.body-html: Sorry, one more fix. Changed the default :limit from 11 to 4, otherwise it'll add :limit in the schema when it doesn't need to since 4 is returned by int, not 11.
version.tag: 2.1 activerecord edge enhancement migrations mysql patch tests
version.title: :limit for primary key columns

version.tag: 2.1 2.2 activerecord edge enhancement migrations mysql patch tests
version.title: :limit for primary key columns

version.body:
Why is the patch changing the default limit in NATIVE_DATABASE_TYPES ? Also, the default schema dumper shouldn't be changed here.
Considering the complexity of the patch and the gains by it, I'm inclined to suggest you just use change_column instead of trying to change the limit when creating the table. Does that work for you ?
Thanks.
version.body-html:
Why is the patch changing the default limit in NATIVE_DATABASE_TYPES ? Also, the default schema dumper shouldn't be changed here.

Considering the complexity of the patch and the gains by it, I'm inclined to suggest you just use change_column instead of trying to change the limit when creating the table. Does that work for you ?

Thanks.
version.tag: 2.1 2.2 activerecord edge enhancement migrations mysql patch tests
version.title: :limit for primary key columns

version.body:
change_column ignores the limit option for primary keys so that doesn't work.
Although the patch looks a little big, it actually simplifies the existing code by making primary keys less of a special case. I think this is ideally what you want.
The change in NATIVE_DATABASE_TYPES isn't really a change. Remember that the byte sizes in MySQL get translated to string lengths by the type_to_sql function. 4 is the equivalent byte size for a string length of 11.
I used this patch a lot in a previous project and never had a single problem with it.
version.body-html:
change_column ignores the limit option for primary keys so that doesn't work.

Although the patch looks a little big, it actually simplifies the existing code by making primary keys less of a special case. I think this is ideally what you want.

The change in NATIVE_DATABASE_TYPES isn't really a change. Remember that the byte sizes in MySQL get translated to string lengths by the type_to_sql function. 4 is the equivalent byte size for a string length of 11.

I used this patch a lot in a previous project and never had a single problem with it.
version.tag: 2.1 2.2 activerecord edge enhancement migrations mysql patch tests
version.title: :limit for primary key columns

version.body: Actually, to expand on what I just said about change_column not working, it's not merely a case of allowing the limit option to take effect because output from the schema dumper still doesn't reflect the new size.
version.body-html: Actually, to expand on what I just said about change_column not working, it's not merely a case of allowing the limit option to take effect because output from the schema dumper still doesn't reflect the new size.
version.tag: 2.1 2.2 activerecord edge enhancement migrations mysql patch tests
version.title: :limit for primary key columns

version.body:
Alright. So this patch should probably make change_column work too, if it's not too much work.
Also, I'm not yet so sure about changing schema dumper to always have :id => false. I wonder if it's possible to do that only if the supplied :limit, :name are different from the default
But the rest looks good.
Thanks !
version.body-html:
Alright. So this patch should probably make change_column work too, if it's not too much work.

Also, I'm not yet so sure about changing schema dumper to always have :id => false. I wonder if it's possible to do that only if the supplied :limit, :name are different from the default

But the rest looks good.

Thanks !
version.tag: 2.1 2.2 activerecord edge enhancement migrations mysql patch tests
version.title: :limit for primary key columns

version.body:
The patch already fixes change_column. There is still a " type != :primary_key" condition in the base definition of type_to_sql but the MySQL definition deals with primary keys before this line is reached. The condition should be left there for the other databases because I don't think they allow you to set the size of the primary key like MySQL does.
Preventing :id => false except when necessary makes it a little messier but very similar to how it was originally so it's no big deal. Here's an updated patch with that included against current edge.
version.body-html:
The patch already fixes change_column. There is still a " type != :primary_key" condition in the base definition of type_to_sql but the MySQL definition deals with primary keys before this line is reached. The condition should be left there for the other databases because I don't think they allow you to set the size of the primary key like MySQL does.

Preventing :id => false except when necessary makes it a little messier but very similar to how it was originally so it's no big deal. Here's an updated patch with that included against current edge.
version.tag: 2.1 2.2 activerecord edge enhancement migrations mysql patch tests
version.title: :limit for primary key columns

version.body: Just realised the call to "compact" in the schema dumper can now be removed.

 t.string "nick", :null => false
 t.string "name"
 "> expected to be =~ </t.primary_key\s+"id",\s+:limit => \d+$/>.

version.body:
Thanks guys. I tried to update the patch myself last night but I couldn't get 3.0 to go. Hadn't tried it before.
Just one concern. In schema_dumper.rb, the spec[:limit]= line used to come after the spec[:type]= line. The spec[:limit]= line is conditional on spec[:type] != 'decimal'. That will always be false now. I think you need to rearrange this section a bit.
version.body-html:
Thanks guys. I tried to update the patch myself last night but I couldn't get 3.0 to go. Hadn't tried it before.

Just one concern. In schema_dumper.rb, the spec[:limit]= line used to come after the spec[:type]= line. The spec[:limit]= line is conditional on spec[:type] != 'decimal'. That will always be false now. I think you need to rearrange this section a bit.
version.tag: 3.0 activerecord enhancement migrations mysql patch tests
version.title: :limit for primary key columns

version.body: Sorry, I meant that will always be TRUE now.
version.body-html: Sorry, I meant that will always be TRUE now.

version.title: :limit for primary key columns

version.body:
verified when cherry-picking the original commit to the current HEAD
there is an error when running the tests with mysql and fixtures and using a limit below 4. The reason: the automatically calculated ids for the fixtures which are usually above the range of limits between 1-3 (maximum of 8388607).
Is this patch intended to be used for lowering the limit? My use-case would probably always be increasing the limit to allow for bigger ids. In this case we could just disallow the use of limits below 4. If one would want limits below 4 we would have to adjust the automatically generated number for ids.
version.body-html:
verified when cherry-picking the original commit to the current HEAD

there is an error when running the tests with mysql and fixtures and using a limit below 4. The reason: the automatically calculated ids for the fixtures which are usually above the range of limits between 1-3 (maximum of 8388607).

Is this patch intended to be used for lowering the limit? My use-case would probably always be increasing the limit to allow for bigger ids. In this case we could just disallow the use of limits below 4. If one would want limits below 4 we would have to adjust the automatically generated number for ids.
version.tag: 3.0 activerecord bugmash enhancement migrations mysql patch tests
version.title: :limit for primary key columns

version.body: I'm calling off on this one. Please submit a patch if it's still applicable.
version.body-html: I'm calling off on this one. Please submit a patch if it's still applicable.

version.title: :limit for primary key columns

version.body: I might look at it again once I move up to Rails 3. I don't use MySQL anymore but I don't want to see the effort go to waste. To answer Michael's question, it was to increase the limit.
version.body-html: I might look at it again once I move up to Rails 3. I don't use MySQL anymore but I don't want to see the effort go to waste. To answer Michael's question, it was to increase the limit.
